## Getting started with Git and GitHub

1. Create GitHub account
2. Create a repository
3. Install git
4. Configure git
5. Install GitHub Desktop
6. Clone repository to your computer
7. Make some changes to your repository
8. Push your changes back to GitHub

## Step 1. Create a GitHub account

If you don't already have a GitHub account, go to GitHub.com and create one.

![](pics/github.png)

## Step 2. Create a repository (part 1)

Sign in to your GitHub account and create a new repository.

- make it public
- add a Readme.md file


## Step 2. Create a repository (part 2)

![](pics/new_repo.png)


## Step 3. Install Git

Download and install from here [git](https://git-scm.com/downloads)

## Step 4. Configure git (part 1)

The Git client needs to know who you are before you can start to use it.

- Open your File Explorer
- Right click in any folder
- Select "Git Bash here"

## Step 4. Configure git (part 2)

![](pics/bash.png)

## Step 4. Configure git (part 3)


- git config --global user.name "prvernier"
- git config --global user.email "pierre.vernier@gmail.com"


## Step 5. Install GitHub Desktop

If you'd rather not work at the command line with Git, you can download a GUI client such as GitHub Desktop.

- [GitHub Desktop](https://desktop.github.com/)


## Step 6. Clone repository to your computer

- Open GitHub Desktop and clone the repository you just created.

## Step 7. Make some changes to your repository

- Open your Readme.md file
- Add some text and save it

## Step 8. Push your changes back to GitHub

- Open GitHub Desktop
- Add a comment
- Commit changes
- Push changes

## Step 9. Helful resources

There are many online resources online.

- Do a Google search e.g., "git and github primer"
- [happygitwithr](https://happygitwithr.com/) (excellent one stop resource!)
